reviews.review: Such a pleasure to play! If you ever liked games like Unpacking where you get to see cute pixel item by pixel item pop out of a box and then decide 100% yourself where you want to place them, all while being under no time pressure at all - this one's for you! I loved the anomalies all around, the little plant and alchemy puzzles had me buzzing as well. It's such a chill and pretty game whether it's for achievement hunters (that sweet ping sound!) or for relaxing furniture collecting and room building enthusiasts! I really enjoyed this game.

It's like if Unpacking was set in a whole city and had cute additional story beats threaded throughout. Also, spooky. Not in a bad way. This is such a cute game!
The only whisper here is my mouse begging for mercy. Clicky clicky clack, baby.

Truth time... I LOVED the game Unpacking so so much, so I just knew this one would be right up (or is it down?) my alley. 

Thereâ€™s something so deeply satisfying about unpacking and decorating each little space. Every room has its own story, and I found myself slowing down just to get things â€œright.â€ The whole process scratches that same cozy itch as cleaning or organizing in real life... but minus the mess, of course. 

I also love how much personality it has. There are hidden surprises when you interact with random objects, and a few cheeky pop culture references that actually made me laugh. It feels like the devs had fun making this, and that vibe totally comes through.

100 % done and dusted in 8 ish hours, so I am not unhappy.

A small but excellent game. You furnish apartments and discover curious things along the way. It's not very extensive, but it's a lot of fun and good for achievement hunters. The pixel graphics are really cute.

I really enjoying this game a lot! I love how this game gives us plenty of freedom to unleash our creativity. And the visual it uses pixels which is i really love, and the back sound its so good to hear. Anyway, I highly recommend this game to people who loves decorate room/places.

A great little game, I went in blind and had an amazing time with the story. The decorating is great, satisfying, with lots of details, and the story is really good. It's cute and somewhat philosophical, which I wasn't expecting from this.
I like that I figured out all the little puzzles myself. Nothing is too hard, while not a lot is explained, context clues are all over the place (as well as notes in some homes to help, of course), and after figuring something out, getting that achievement really boosts the incentive to keep playing. 
I like that theirs a mini collection system in the game too, with decorations you can pull from shops. Gotta love a gotcha system.
I had a blast, I only wish it were longer now. I say go in blind if you're into decoration games because this one has a lot of fun secrets you don't want spoiled.

I was looking for another simple and addicting game and came across this one. Best purchase I've ever made! I love the small details that they add in the game to keep you hooked and learn more about each character and even the town itself. If you love organizing games with a good story that leaves mysteries for you to uncover that makes you want more then this is the game for you :3! 

Pros: 
I love the art style and it is aesthetically pleasing
Cats everywhere! 
There is a gacha system (kinda like loot boxes but you don't pay actual money)
Small details that are left to hint at a characters backstory to show it completed meaning they took great care in telling the story not leaving it completely unfinished but leaving it up to gamer to build off and piece together.

I don't any cons as of yet because Idk if they will continue to add more updates to add more to the map or more things to do with your own personal home. Plus I only have 14 hours in the game so far. I hope this helps :)!

I wish there was a "Yes, but" kind of option on Steam. Game took me 8 hours to complete in full with all achievements. I opted to not go out and try to get all the collectible furniture. In the end, I wasn't as drawn to the designing aspect of each room as much as I was during Unpacking. The convenience stores felt very unsatisfying in particular because there didn't feel to be a good way to organize everything to my own satisfaction due to some of the pixel constraints. Not being able to put all the soda bottles in the fridge because only certain rows could double stack, etc.

This was a fun time, don't get me wrong. But I think Unpacking did the UI of this concept much better and with a more cohesive story line and didn't even use words.

Si estÃ¡s buscando algo a lo "Unpacking" recomiendo mucho este juego. 
Es muy relajante estar decorando los lugares.

I was expecting a game more more like Unpacking, Whisper of the House is not that.
This game is much closer to something like decorating homes in The Sims or Animal Crossing's Happy Home Decorator. While I enjoyed the partial puzzle of figuring out how a set collection of furniture can fit together, about half of the game's runtime is "free build".

Being from a Chinese studio, there are some amusing quirks in game design. The only one I would consider a negative being paragraphs of flowery text. Unfortunately any impact the dialogue from characters have is lost in translation.

I really hope the developer puts out DLC for this game because I absolutely loved everything about it, except for how short it was. I crave more fun mysteries to solve while decorating these little spaces. It felt so satisfying to clean up the messes and discover little easter eggs everywhere. I just want MORE, haha. Definitely check this game out and support them, and maybe we will get some kind of update or extra levels in the future~

A relaxing organiser game if you like cleaning, organising and decoration, but just not in your own house. 
Very hard recommend!

Very similar to Unpacking, though it's not as strict about where you put items. I am curious about the story line that is unraveling and the expansion of the characters' stories. I thought this would just be a simple puzzle game, but it appears to be more layered than that. I enjoy the music and the overall art style.

Pretty good light puzzle/unpacking game with exceptionally good art direction.

**MILD SPOILERS**
This game's "dark twist" for each house was probably originally meant to be a lot more realistic and true crime inspired. Based on the first case, but it pulled it back and went a lot more fantastical and light which I didn't like as much.

Still, really good game.

Super cozy and relaxing, but enough of a story line to keep me hooked until the end.
Gurllllll this game is queen slay fire 100%. Cute story, the town feels alive, the pixel art looks beautiful and you can still design the empty lots/showcases after beating the main story. <3

Un juego de ordenar y decorar, pero con un giro de miedo/adulto. Tiene muchas mecanicas muy interesantes, me encantÃ³! me gustaria que aÃ±adan mas misiones o un dlc porque solo son 10 y se termina rapido, y siento que da para mas

This game has so much charm and whimsy to it. I initially got into it for the pixel art and the process of packing stuff away into rooms piece by piece until it looks perfect; but there's so much story and mystery to the game. The main characters have their own backstory and the game plays out beautifully as you find anomalies and charming hidden details in every shop and home you work in. Even though the day is passing there's no pressure to complete a project immediately so you can take your time to figure out where everything goes and interact with different objects for fun little secrets. I received this product as a gift but I would have no issues spending full price. A lovely cosy game to pass the time.

I had added the game to my wishlist because it was about furnishing houses and I liked the idea. But it's much more than that! You are in a pixel art world with lots of people to talk to, lots of cats to pet, and lots of things to collect or clean.
It's a very lovely game made with love and attention. There are lots of (side)quests, the achievements are easy to obtain and it's just so easy to play this game.
11/10 would clean again.
(Received this game as a birthday gift.)

If you liked Unpacking but thought "hey, this needs more diversity of rooms to unpack things in, and also could use, like, cryptic shit and magic"? This game's for you.
Cosy gameplay, charming art style, and I liked the puzzly bits.

This game has everything you need to forguet you are in the midel of a crisis. Humor, mistery, decoration and a lot of confusion on the characters life choices with their interior decoration.

A game for when your parents argue or you have a thesis to complete, or both!

One of my absolute favourites.

Combo cozy and spooky elements. I love it. It's like the Unpacking game but longer, more immersive, and has a little world with it.  I play on the steamdeck so there are some bugs, but not complaining because it's not branded for the steamdeck. I do wish there was an option to make text a little bigger to read (a me problem on the deck).
I have been having so much fun playing this game! Its cozy, mysterious, the graphics adorable. Easy to pick up, hard to put down. I do wish the controls were a little better on steamdeck.

This game caught my interest for the cleaning, organizing, and chance to put a room together. Its de-stressing for me and made me happy when I loaded it up. The small town and chance to make a difference in a "community" was nice as well. I found the game too quick, would have loved a chance to go back and redo some or have an opportunity to reset the space and start again. The magician's space was my favorite with the large room and upper floors as well. Wish I could have chosen to make it the main home for my character. I highly recommend but encourage people to take their time.

Cute, but very, VERY short and there's no actual ending unless you find every anomaly, in which case you get credits. Otherwise, you just suddenly stop getting missions and that's it. 
It feels like a lot of wasted potential, especially considering most characters and "secrets" never come back and very few of the buildings are ever used.
EXCELLENT! Scratches that exact itch. Tons of customization, tons of items, tons of level. Lots of secrets and the town feels alive.

I really enjoyed this game, it was giving all the right organising vibes (just like Unpacking, which I've been looking for similar games for a while now) with added mystery and story :) 

A nice cozy game all round :)

Highly recommend. If you are like me and have played Unpacking 20 times and are really sad they aren't making another one, this is the game for you! SO engrossing and satisfying and fun.

I love this game, it's short and cute and I love the achievements. It is such a satisfying game to play, if you are looking for a cute, fun, organizational, and mysterious game then give this a try!

Such a cute game. I love the decorations, characters and music. The story is so fun too. Would love to see this game expanded in the future!

One of the best games ive played for a while, I love the cozy vibe it brings and felt very stress free. I played unpacking on xbox and this reminds me of it but with so much more! The plot was interesting and I found the anomalies part cool and a good extra bit for the game. Def want to see more games like this!!! 10/10

Super fun! If you love unpacking, this is a great game similar to the style of unpacking with the isometric pixel graphics and gameplay. It's not just unpacking either, there's tons of content where you can buy homes or showrooms to furnish with what you find through gameplay as well. If you're a sims 4/house flipper/any furnishing game then you'll definitely like that aspect of freedom too. Lots of variety, lots of challenges, plenty of content. The story is cute, the localization is fine (devs are chinese - the game has plenty of chinese culture referenced in it, but also has seasonal decor from other cultures worldwide. the dia de los muertos stuff was a pleasant surprise lmao) 
highly, highly, highly recommend. the price of the game compared to the content is absolutely stellar!
Such a fun little game! Like Unpacking but a little bit more story and secrets

This is such a cozy game for me! It combined the unboxing game and decorating homes, try to figure out the weird things around the city. I played 4 hours stray and still have not done with it yet! A lot of varieties of furniture around the map that you can roll for by using voucher, which is so easy to get! Highly recommend this game!!

If you liked Unpacking, you'll like this! Gorgeous art direction, cozy organizing gameplay, and lots of cute and funny dialogue.

Absolutely loved this game. The music and aesthetic has a comforting feel to it. Time went by so fast while I was playing. A very nice feel good game. Highly recommend.

Cozy interior design game, you're free to set the rooms whatever way you want. Choice of items feel a little limited after some time, including interior layouts. I think it still has a lot of room to expand on down the line, so it's worth the purchase even at full price.

So far, this game is super cute with lots to do. A little eerie in some ways too!! I love the customization and each house you clean is its own unique creative puzzle to solve. Make sure you're checking for multiple rooms! :) 

Was looking for a calming, cozy games after all the competitive I play. Safe to say, this is going to be my cozy game for a little bit ^_^

There are a few glitches here and there such as the gift boxes not transferring to storage when I try to click to move them so atm, I have a gift box in my basement lol. Hopefully that is just user error on my part or as time goes on, these things sort themselves. Devs seem to be very on top of it :)

Gameplay, story, and writing felt half-baked. Still, very pretty pixel art for the city and interiors, with a staggering amount of furniture choices, so the game will still be fun for people who just want to decorate houses

i liked it. its cute and fun. for the price and the size of the map i was expecting a few more "levels"  but still fun and i can still fuck around and decorate if i want. it also sorta feels like they were setting up more with the story and like it being a "horror" game but  then it just sorta ends idk feels like there could be more. still cute and fun

If you like Unpacking or decorating then I highly recommend this game. I like the mysteries as well! I've heard the main story is relatively short which is a bummer cuz I've been really enjoying it, but the main mechanics of the game are fun on their own! I hope they continue to add more to this game

Very fun, casual play with some quests here and there and surprises. Very cute, asmr but short, however there's tons of hidden things to look for

This is a really cute and cozy game. It's very relaxing to play, and has some beautiful art direction, animation, and music. There are some wonky parts to it- it isn't the most intuitive thing to play (I had to use a walk-through because the game doesn't explain much to you), and it does have some English localization issues (I can understand everything as a native English speaker, but I did have to read some things a few times to understand what the game meant). Overall, though, it is a pretty enjoyable game that clearly had a lot of love poured into it. It's a decent investment if you're looking to play a relatively short game that has some chill post-game content. I managed to beat the game in about eight hours of laid-back play, but I can still continue to play and decorate little houses.

Adorable little game that you can 100% in about 7 hours.
Very similar to unpacking- organize and clean rooms around town to progress through the story. Little-to-no replayability for me, personally, unless they add content or update the game. As a standalone, short solo-player game, though, it's very cute and worth playing through once.
was in desperate need of a new cozy game that wasn't just repeating some old favorites. this is cute and fun, and sometimes a little creepy. thank u for saving me, i was so thirsty

There are a lot of items that are beautifully animated; makes it fun to interact with each object. The gacha elements to get various furniture also makes it more fun to collect them all. Some darker elements in the game were a bit unexpected, although they contribute to its uniqueness. In overall, a cute & cozy game to play & decorate to your heart's content!

Perfect, I have nothing to complain about, just one of my favorites games
Super cute game with a nice balance between interior decoration, item collecting, secret-hunting, and storyline!

I love this game so much! It's similar to Unpacking where you help people unpack, organize, and decorate. I love the pixel art style and the secrets you can find all over the town. The tiny cats you can pet are super cute too. Some of the town folks you help also have really interesting stories.
è¶…å¥½ç©ï¼å–œæ¬¢è£…ä¿®çš„æœ‰ç¦äº† å°±æ˜¯æµç¨‹å¤ªçŸ­äº† å¸Œæœ›åç»­èƒ½æ›´æ–°æ–°çš„åœ°å›¾

This game has everything I could ever want; a cozy soundtrack, adorable pixel graphics, easy chill game play with no time limits, and being able to design your own house with so many options and themes for furniture and decor. This game has it all with a slightly unsettling twist! I can't wait to keep playing and make so many cozy and perfect rooms!

I personally loved the game. The world feels really lively considering you can wander the streets, pet stray cats, pick up trash, and talk to people. Organizing rooms and enjoying the "spooky" anomalies was especially calming. The game motivates you to interact with the objects you are unpacking or organizing. That being said, it is not that hard to find the anomalies and such. Some may think that is a bad thing, but I believe the game is charming in that it is easy to do the task you set out to do and relax. If you are looking for a spooky game, Whisper of the House is not it. However, it is still enjoyable regardless. The game reminds me of the game "Unpacking" which I also enjoyed a ton!

Charming game with a gently spooky vibe. Very cute art, and decorating homes and learning the simple storylines is pretty fun. 
Not too long, either.

8.5/10
I like furnishing houses but my favourite was the alchemists place that we had to clean up and reorganize ğŸ¤¤
I do like the idea of the show rooms that have to be decorated but I'm not really creative enough for that. Finally, I do love opening mystery boxes but there needs to be an option to open like 5 or 10 at a time  cause it takes forever if you want to collect all the items
Jut an adorable, satisfying, and perfectly executed unpacking game. You won't regret it.

I absolutely LOVED the demo for this, and the game itself is so *chef's kiss*

If you loved playing decorating flash games, I highly recommend this. The little details really bring this game together (yes you can pet the cats!!!) the hidden story lines help make this deeper than what originally appears. Will probably play this game over and over.
Comprei achando que era um joguinho sobre limpar e decorar casinhas e acabei num culto de Eldritch Horror. E aÃ­ eu voltei a limpar e decorar casinhas. Absolutamente 10/10.

It's a very cute decorating game with some fun mystery twists here and there. The gameplay is pretty average of this type of game, if not a bit limited. The pixel art is amazing and very expressive. Overall, if you like a game where you decorate homes you'll most likely like it. If you like solving mysteries, you'll have fun with all the secrets the game holds.

A couple of things I didn't really like:
- The decorating feels kind of limited. You can't change the color of most items and the color selection is very limited, even with the color picker tool. You can't really mess with saturation all that much and some colors come out very bright or very dark.

- Almost all the bathrooms were absolutely tiny so you are very limited to how much detail you can put in them. You can't even change the shape of your bathroom and are stuck with the walk in shower set up.

-The ending felt a little disappointing but it does wrap everything up nicely. So it wasn't a bad ending just a bit anti-climatic.

*SPOILERS*


- The houses you get as rewards near the end of the game are basically just theme rooms and you can't change the wallpaper or flooring. Which I find very odd, since you given these homes and not like, reselling them/renting them out.
Such a good game, it reminded me a lot of unpacking but somehow better with a lot more options.
One of the best games ive played! Super fun and addictive! Just wish there were more levels...
This game is amazing. I really loved it and definitely makes my bi annual replay list.

A nice game where you can organise houses/rooms to your own choosing 
A few things that could be tweaked would be more option to rotate and customise objects
Great cozy and comfort game, not forcing you to rush anything just relax and enjoy the game while uncover some mysteries at the town
Really nice and cosy game, i really liked the decorating and cleaning but i love how the story goes and i was totally into looking for the artifact !

Great cozy game! Really relaxing music and gameplay loop, fun mechanics and if you  love interior decorating or tidying up, you'll love this! Will be back to play this when i need a cozy relaxing time!

Incredibly addicting and fun decorating/organizing game. You have quite a lot of freedom to place the items basically anywhere you want. The game on release had a wide variety of furniture and decor. I hope it keeps receiving updates! My only real complain is that there is no character customization and the gameplay gets extremely repetitive after you complete the main story line. The side jobs repeat frequently, it starts to feel like there is really nothing else to do. Overall it's great and definitely worth the $15. <3

I absolutely ADORE cozy games (and more so when they've got a little kick to them). Whisper of the House (WotH) is a charming and cute indie pixel art game where you work as an interior designer by helping clients settle in the town. But that aside, you also notice over time how some tidbits look and feel unusual and mysterious - creepy, even. 

Comparing this to Unpacking is a disservice to both games! While both are about making a home, WotH feels more free; in a sense that the player can place whatever they want wherever. Not only do you get to decorate people's houses as well, but also your own! It's an optional side that you can do with an extra feature of gacha on furniture by using "tickets" you get from completing missions and rummaging through trash (which is the best part of the game fr)

In comparison to Unpacking, WotH feels more episodic. It places value in each client's personal story through the way they want their home decorated in contrast to Unpacking where you only really look at only one person's life. Despite this difference, both games are outstanding in their own right and both WotH AND Unpacking are very deserving of praise for its cozy, comforting, and zen vibe.

Overall, this game is wonderful and if you're an avid cozy game enjoyer for room designing w really good graphic and visual design like me, you are sure to love experiencing this game as much as I did. Easiest 9/10!

The church in the graveyard honestly made me extremely anxious, but thatâ€™s part of what makes the game so engaging. It balances that uneasy atmosphere with moments of calm and curiosity, creating a really unique experience.

Overall, itâ€™s a relaxing game with just the right touch of mystery and eeriness. Perfect if you enjoy slow-paced exploration and light puzzle-solving with a slightly spooky twist!

Thank you Developer for this wonderfully cute game! I appreciate the time invested in this work and I really hope to see more!

Absolutely loved the demo and knew I had to buy it when it finally released!

Love the game so much! Will highly recommend it if you enjoy games like Unpacking and wish you could do the same for other NPC's and not just for the main character. There is such a variety in tasks you need to do (Decorate your own home / Unpack how you want / Unpack but the way I want you to / I have this idea with a few items and want you to add to it) which makes every task feel different! Not to mention the subtle storylines going on as well!

Only downside is that the main story with the pyramid feels a bit out of place? Might be cause it wasn't there during the demo, but the way it ties in to our experience felt a bit out of place (might just be me though, but I kind of thought there would be more to it based on how strange some of the 'glitch' interactions were).

I think we also get wayyyy too much vouchers for tasks (and too quickjly)! Let us grind and work for those furnishing pieces to decorate our homes! I do love that the gatcha furnishing stores prioritise giving you new items rather than copies of already-obtained versions (you can buy copies at the mall at least!) to ensure that you can unlock all items easier rather than it being a pure gatcha.

Played this game for 6 hours straight -- super simple premise but each room is unique enough that game play doesn't get repetitive. There's also a good balance between the amount of "clutter" items and storage options that no room feels too cramped or full -- while also feeling lived in. I'd say the [spoiler]bakery and grocery stores[/spoiler] are the most difficult to keep from looking too cluttered but it adds to the fun imo.

I have been looking for cozy games to play that are relaxing but intriguing. I downloaded this game last night and played for over 4 hours into the wee hours of the morning (3 am lol). This game is amazingly put together. Along with satisfying organizational tasks/game play, there is an overarching story that I have barely scratched the surface of. So many things about this game are beautiful: the graphics, the sound track, the story so far. I am so happy I stumbled upon this game!

This game was exactly what I wanted and then some. The two things that take this game from great to incredible are: 1) The open-world aspect filled with looting and bonus adventures, and 2) A rich storyline with comedy and mystery combined. They still nailed all of the basics too. The cozy unpacking and decorating gameplay is excellent. The furniture/decor collection progress is great, there is a broad range of decor types and level challenges to incentivize progress. At around 10 hours, I feel like I still have a lot of creative fun and exploration left and I can't wait to see where this game continues to go.

This is a lovely game that's fairly short. The dev team is still actively working on it and doing bug fixes so I won't mention the ones I've encountered as I'm sure they're already fixed. It has a tame but still present unnerving vibe(?) It's hard to explain and I don't think spooky really describes the feeling and atmosphere but I would describe it as mildly disturbing in the sense you might feel a tad uneasy. This feeling is very scant and only really ramps up in the latter end of the game and i enjoyed it as it adds a layer of suspense. That said, the ending feels accurate to the story's progression but it falls a bit flat. Just a tad underwhelming and the plot of the game is very minimal.

Despite the minimal plot, I enjoyed the overall game because I love organizing simulators and it's art style adds a fresh and exciting look to it compared to most other organization simulators (the only other organization game that ive played that has pixel art like whisper of the house is Unpacking by Witchbeam). I like the customization but i feel it could be more robust. All in all, it's a solid game it just might not be as polished as one may expect as the devs are still finding their footing for the game, but I don't mind that as the gameplay is the main draw for me and this game definitely has some replayability for me.

A very cute pixel organizing game similar to "Unpacking", albeit with a background Christian bent, where "Unpacking" was made by a Jewish developer and had Jewish elements (which is unfortunately rather unique in the video game space). That being said, "Whisper of the House" was a bit more enjoyable than "Unpacking" in some ways, in that the quests were quite fun, it didn't crash (though it had a number of lag issues that looked like near-crashes), and it identified objects for the player to move around. It's also a little longer and there's more stuff to do, although that made it a bit overwhelming at times, and I think the game is more targeted at people who like to make cute house designs than people who just like organizing things.

One of my main criticisms of "Unpacking" was that I didn't know what all the objects you handle were, so it was hard to figure out which room was the correct one for them. Although "Whisper of the House" generally sticks you in the right room for whatever object you're given (with the option of switching rooms as needed, though this is rarely necessary outside personal desire), the game also not only names whatever the object is, but also describes it. The descriptions aren't always useful, but the naming is.

There are issues with near-crashing: whenever a character would I think leave a screen, the screen would go entirely black, and the game would very obviously lag. During the end cutscene, the game froze, and then jumped a couple seconds forward. I also recall dealing with leg on clicking things at times (particularly with the gacha stuff), which was frustrating. While I appreciate the game is self-contained and has no microtransactions while containing gacha design elements, like games like "Vampire Survivors", I found this pretty aggravating because it does the "Kirby and the Forgotten Land" thing, where you can get repeat items rather than drawing from a narrower pool. This was irritating in "Astro Bot" as well, where you could spend hard-earned money to buy junk instead of items from the remaining pool. Considering just how many items there are in the game and how many pulls you have to do on average for them, it's very silly that you can collect things you already have when doing pulls, especially when it has no microtransactions so there's no intelligent reason to keep people making pulls, other than that's just how gacha tends to work.

The pixel art is very cute, and I appreciated the slight "Stardew Valley" and "Gravity Falls" vibes, with plenty of clear love for Studio Ghibli. The game does feel a bit overwhelming in moments, with a fast day-to-night cycle (that admittedly doesn't do anything other than matter for I think one item), and a small deluge of quests you get at once, until you discover everything is basically optional and the map has a pin system so you can set markers for yourself to go to if you get lost. The freedom and sense of narrative is nice, but I did appreciate "Unpacking"'s more linear narrative.

I was also really confused, from a narrative angle, why the game keeps giving you [spoiler]homes to live in. By the time the ending rolled around, I'd gotten a handful of places to live in, on top of living rent free(?) in two different apartments, so I was a bit confused why I was meant to be excited about being gifted a house and too much stuff to stick in it, cute as the furniture is[/spoiler]. This is why I pointed out that the game seems more geared towards folks who like rearranging pretty fake houses than folks who like organizing, because this game design aspects seems to be geared towards giving the former more of what they want. And that's great for the former, but a bit underwhelming if you're not as into that part and just want puzzle-solving. I'm also a bit disappointed [spoiler]we didn't get to have a pet. The mysterious dog is never explained, and we don't get to keep the cat(s) that are wandering around. But I did appreciate the aquarium[/spoiler]. Additionally, while the town is nice, [spoiler]it's mostly empty. So the town aspect (rather than just focused on building to building, as "Unpacking" does) felt a bit wasted, since most of the neat-looking buildings and areas aren't places you can visit[/spoiler]. I also wish there were more buildings with [spoiler]people showing you where to put things. I get it defeats the purpose for some stuff, but it was satisfying in its own way[/spoiler].

From a designer point, storage was also quite irritating. The [spoiler]present boxes are very cute, for instance, but you can neither store nor even trash them, so they just filled up my basement[/spoiler].

It was also very weird to find [spoiler]when you click the cop car, whoever's in it says "Comrade", like... the  pigs are communists? I'm so confused. I also wonder why a police station that serves no purpose (other than removing an unhoused person off-screen) was more important than other town facilities, like a dump or a school[/spoiler].

This can also be very hard on your hands, given some segments require continuous clicking. "Gemporium" actually had an accessibility feature for this, allowing a single button press to replace multiple ones. It was frustrating not to see that here.

Generally, though, it's a simple little game, with cute designs and fun puzzles. If you liked "Unpacking", you'll probably like this. If you liked this, you should try "Unpacking".

EDIT: This a very engaging puzzle game. The first quest is tonally a little off for me, but I enjoy that quite a bit of the puzzles have some unique mechanic to it.

I highly recommend this game if you love decorating and cute things sprinkled with a lil bit of dark mystery in the storyline. ++ You won't be judged for digging in the trash like in stardew.

All that said I did pour 12 numbed-out hours into this before I felt like there was nothing left for me, which is pretty good value for the sale price.

fun relaxing game. perfect to chill and smoke

When the creators of Unpacking said they had no intention of making a follow up game, I was stung. This game soothed that burn. It's relaxed, comforting, and highly interactive. I beat the main story and still have some little areas to work on, which I fully intend to do. I deeply enjoyed this game. With that being said, yes I'm going to be that person. It would have been nice to have a customized character. There really isn't a reason why we have to choose between two genders and one skin tone in 2025. It could have just been pick the body frame, pick the skin tone, pick the hair, and be done with it. That was my only hang up with this game. That, and a tiny bit more guidance could have been given.  However, this game easily paid for itself.

Super chill unpacking, room designing, organizing game with a hint of mystery! Love the pixel art and the PLANTS. Love the ability to revisit rooms to add or adjust as more furniture and wares are unlocked. Beautiful game to 100% and continue to customize.

LOVED this one, super cute furniture and little secrets I had fun discovering. I hope over time a bunch more content is added because I finished the main stuff pretty quickly. Totally worth your time, just a cute asf indie game.
very relaxing game, similar vibes to unpacking. Love the art, music, super relaxing

It's not a very long game, unless you like putting together rooms from a full set of furniture - which, you might. I prefer the "stages", where I have a set amount of things to put out, so the game is pretty much over for me now. But it was very charming - I liked it a lot. The puzzles weren't too hard, I didn't have to look anything up, and figuring out everything was very satisfying.
I would rec this game to fans of Unpacking - that's what I thought it might be like, and I was right!

This is like unpacking on steroids and I LOVED every second of it. SO many furniture options and the only limit is your imagination. I played it all the way through in 1 sitting because the game is addicting. 

I'd say its around 6-8 hours to finish, maybe 9 or 10 if you're trying to get all the achievements like I did. 

10/10 recommended: very peaceful, satisfying game play that includes intriguing story elements. 

I've been looking for this type of game for forever and it fulfilled my expectations and beyond. I want to find more similar indie games like this, or I hope the developers make a sequel!

At its core its obviously heavily inspired by "unpacking". but it offers a much more varieties of gameplay, some levels can be finished with your brain completely shut down, but some require certain level of creativity.
Frankly speaking i was just expecting a overpriced unpacking clone, but turn out its a evolved version with lot of contents, what a surprise!
If you've ever played Unpacking and wished there were more levels, the ability to design your own rooms, and/or underlying mysteries, this is the game for you!

æ€»ä½“48è¿˜æ˜¯è´µäº†çœ‹çœ‹éš”å£æ˜Ÿéœ²è°·é‚£ä¹ˆå¤šä¸œè¥¿æ‰å®šä»·å››åå¤šï¼Œå¦‚æœè¿™æ˜¯ä¸ªè£…ä¿®æ¸¸æˆè¯·è®¤çœŸå¼€å‘è£…ä¿®ç›¸å…³äº‹é¡¹ï¼Œè®©ç”¨æˆ·æœ‰ä¸ªè‰¯å¥½çš„è£…ä¿®ä½“éªŒï¼Œç›®å‰ä¸ºæ­¢ç»™ç¾æœ¯å’ŒéŸ³ä¹ç‚¹èµï¼Œè¿™ä¿©èƒ½å€¼äºŒåï¼Œå‰©ä¸‹28å¦‚åŒæ‰“æ°´æ¼‚

i would recommend this game, but i do have complicated feelings about it. 
this game is incredibly charming and reeaallyyy fun. the unpacking mechanics are so nice and having the different levels makes it really enjoyable and unique. I am so captivated by the tiny glimpses of story you get with each level, but at the same time I feel confused talking to npcs. Each narrative is so random and kind of half baked, it makes me want more but they're so short lived and inconclusive that it leaves me feeling pretty dissatisfied. This game is kind of mysterious, which I like, but the 15 levels available don't feel like enough to me. You kind of get thrown all of these levels, and then everything comes to a stand still. I walked around the town for half an hour trying to figure out what I was missing. 
I just think for a game that is so interesting at it's core, it needs a more structured playing experience.

This 100% scratches that itch you get after playing a game like Unpacking. Itâ€™s all about organising and decorating, but without the stress of putting things in the 'right' place. You get to decide where everything goes, and the pixel art / world design is adorable. 

Achievements can be earned passively, and you won't miss any opportunities to go back and get them as the world is extremely open.

A game about helping sort their house/business, but with a mystery looming in the background. It looks beautiful, and it is so much fun to uncover more and more. No missable achievements and completion takes around 7 hours. 

[b]Approximate time to 100%:[/b] Around 7 hours
[b]Estimated achievement difficulty:[/b] 1/10
[b]Minimum number of playthroughs needed:[/b] 1
[b]Is there a good guide available:[/b] Yes, I used this one: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3556988145
[b]Multiplayer achievements:[/b] No
[b]Missable achievements:[/b] No, you can return to the town after the ending
[b]Grinding Achievements:[/b] No
[b]DLC-Only achievements:[/b] No
[b]Speedrun achievements:[/b] No
[b]Time-gated achievements:[/b] No
[b]RNG-achievements:[/b] A tiny bit, the achievement "Failed to Take in" requires some luck, but buy the big box with more items to go faster, and maybe save before purchasing the items in case you don't get it. I'm unsure if that is even possible. I still had a lot of credits when I got it.
[b]Does difficulty affect achievements:[/b] No difficulty option, you can use the in-game hints during missions
[b]Unobtainable/glitched achievements:[/b] No
[b]Gamepad or mouse and keyboard:[/b] Mouse and Keyboard

As someone who enjoyed Unpacking but wished it told a little bit more of a story, this one fills that gap. I was already blown away by how gorgeous the game looks, but having the unpacking gameplay combined with a mystery to solve and helping people sort/clean their properties was so much fun! I also love that we have a robot helper. Please don't ask how the box he is holding contains all those items, as that is a mystery in itself. But your robot buddy is so cute! 

What is also nice is that most of the time, you have a choice between properties to go for; in the end, you'll do them all, but it is nice that the game gives you the option of which one you want to do next. Walking around the town to find weird stuff is also so much fun. Later on, you'll unlock a bus pass so you don't have to walk all the way, but I kinda never used it, as I even enjoyed the time strolling through town, and the city isn't so big that it takes a long time.

There are a few missions where some items have a fixed spot, but most of the missions you're totally free to place items wherever you want. Most people who enjoy this type of game would like to organize the items, and that is totally possible, but there isn't a "wrong" spot for an item. You have a lot of freedom. There are also side objectives and dailies, which offer even more freedom to design the house however you want. However, those are optional and not required for the achievements.

Speaking about the achievements, none of them are missable. There are a lot tied to the missions, but there are always secrets within the missions and secrets to find in the town. They aren't missable because you can continually re-enter a building and change things around, or research through them again. What may not be clear from the start is that if you see a glitched item, keep clicking on it with the right mouse button until it is no longer glitching. You'll also unlock an achievement at that point. 

After going through the ending, you get back into town and can still enter houses. Playing through it yourself first and then looking up solutions to things you couldn't find is a valid strategy and highly recommended. It's just so much fun figuring it out by yourself! 

I give Whisper of the House 4.5 out of 5 stars. 


[code]Do you enjoy games that don't have missable achievements? Check out this list on my website: 
[url=https://www.missitheachievementhuntress.com/games-with-unmissable-achievements/]Missi the Achievement Huntress: Games without missable achievements[/url][/code]

Have you ever wanted to move to a mysterious town to become a housekeeper, interior designer, and paranormal investigator all at once? Well boy do I have the game for you! Whisper of the House drops you into a cute and vibrant little town, where the townspeople will pay you to clean, organize, and design homes and businesses. But you start to encounter some... weird objects, not to mention the anonymous and vaguely threatening letters you start receiving in the mail. 

Oh, and you can pet cats!

The gameplay primarily consists of completing jobs for the townspeople (which progresses the story), fixing "anomalies," decorating your own homes (you start with one, and acquire 2 more throughout the game), and taking "model home" requests. There are also a few minigames -- making potions, mixing drinks, and growing unique plants (which you can then use to decorate with). Finally, you can wander around the town, which is just so cute and cozy!! It's rewarding to explore, because there are anomalies and secrets hidden around town, and sometimes you'll also run into characters you've helped previously. You can also raid crates and trash cans to find items, and you can find tokens scattered around.

The decorating mechanics are super simple and satisfying! Everything you pick up/set down makes a little sound that relates to what it is, which I love. The organization and decorating are VERY reminiscent of unpacking (another game I love, and probably a majority of Whisper players also love, LOL) but Whisper is more focused on the aesthetic/creativity aspect than the organization aspect (for example, there are a lot less drawers/cabinets to organize things in; there are a few, but mostly items are placed where they're visible). You can layer certain objects and even cause some objects to interact with each other (such as the ice cream cones and ice cream maker) to create new ones. 

Different jobs require different things from you as the housekeeper -- some are more focused on cleaning, some require you to place items in specific spots, and some simply ask you to decorate as you see fit. One of the cool things about this game is the variety of places you get to work on -- not only homes and apartments, but also different businesses, and even a cemetery. 

There is a huge variety of items, some of which make up themed sets. Furniture, appliances, decor, print items, plants, rugs, and food/drink can all be bought at different stores and vending machines around town, which are marked on the map. They're acquired through a blind box/gacha mechanic, but it's really easy to get tokens, so it's not stressful or difficult to unlock all the items. You'll be paid tokens after each job, when you're "promoted" by the company, and after completing model home requests. 

At the mall, you can buy duplicates of any furniture you have unlocked. For food and drink, you can buy duplicates at the convenience stores, and for plants, at the Flower Shop. I spent SO MUCH time just decorating and making spaces look cute and cozy, I'm sure I could have finished the game faster but I was having so much fun. There are no time penalties or deadlines, so I suggest taking it at whatever pace you want! 

Throughout the game, you get to know some really fun characters and help them with more than just organizing their homes. The little character stories are actually really heartwarming and adorable! Make sure to return to the homes and businesses you worked on, because some of the characters have secondary requests. I thought I was stuck for a while because no more requests were triggering, but I still had a missing character and anomalies... turns out I didn't know how to trigger one of the character's secondary requests. 

Overall, the game is pretty straightforward, and you can get most of the achievements and find most of the anomalies as long as you thoroughly explore and investigate everything. I got around 80/89 achievements by myself, and used a guide for the rest. There are a few things that are a little convoluted, the worst one (in my opinion) being the issue I mentioned before about triggering a characters request. Quick spoilers ahead in the following paragraph:

/BEGIN SPOILERS/

I got stuck after having completed all but one of the jobs in town, because I didn't know how to trigger Luna's secondary request. I had found the secret room and even interacted with the mousetrap, but when I returned to talk to her in response to her letter, I didn't get the hint about what I was supposed to do. She says something like "I hear sobbing at night, and noises in the bathroom." Ok, so I thought, I need to go check the secret room again as well as the bathroom. I click around, nothing happens. What you're meant to do is take the mousetrap from the secret room, put it in the bathroom, then wait a day and you'll receive a Daily Whisper about a homeless person being found in her apartment, as well as a letter from her asking you to come help her again (her secondary request). Honestly I don't get how you're expected to figure that out, the mousetrap is just one of many random cluttered items in the secret room and she makes no mention of rats or animals of any kind, just "noises" and "sobbing." I think if she had said something like "I wonder if there are animals?" after mentioning the noises, it might have clicked? I dunno if this is just me but that was frustrating because you're meant to finish that quest line early in the game, but I didn't get to it until near the end when I finally looked at a guide.

/END SPOILERS/ 

Besides my issue with Luna's requests, I only have small complaints about the game. Honestly, it instantly became one of my favorites -- it's just basically everything I love in one game. But here are my small criticisms, and some requests:

-All items should be able to be rotated all 4 ways. Certain items in the game can only be rotated 2 ways. Also, sometimes items that normally CAN be rotated 4 ways become locked into 2-way rotation when they're stacked (ex. a TV on top of a TV stand: both items by themselves can normally rotate 4 ways, but when stacked, they can't. If you un-stack them, rotate them to the position you want, then stack them again, it works). 
-Please add a search function for the storage! The filters are sometimes helpful, but sometimes not so much. Especially once you have all the items, finding a specific one can be very tedious. I think the best solution would be the option to search items by name. Being able to narrow down into smaller categories would also be good (ex. "bedframes," "computers")
-This one is probably a long shot, and it's not so much a criticism as just a request for future development. I would looveeee character customization! Doesn't have to be crazy or anything, but a few hair styles/colors and different outfits would be amazing. It made me sad looking at the cute clothes and wigs used as decor items in the game and wishing my character could wear them T_T
-Also perchance a long shot but... pets? Cats are a pretty big part of the game, and there's already the coding allowing us to pet the ones in town, plus lots of pet-related decor items. I would love it if we could take in a cat (or dog) that could either just sit or walk around one of our houses (and could be pet of course). 
-And finally... please more content!!! Pretty please a sequel or DLC or something. I want more jobs and more Whisper Town lore!!! No pressure, I know it takes time and effort but I hope there will be more eventually! <3

I miss my Grandpa. This game is worth playing for that little side story alone, for me.

this game is unpacking on steroids in the best possible way. i went into this game expecting a simple unpacking game but it surprised me with soo much more. the charming pixel art style immediately pulled me in. i love how interactive the world is. i love exploring the lil town, interacting with all the items & decor that makes cute lil animations + sound effects. its one of those games u can sit down with n get carried away for hours with organizing n decorating. i play this on steam deck & it runs flawlessly. such a perfect perfect cozy game to play in bed. 10/10 game for sure â™¡

I'm going to give this game a recommended because it is enjoyable, the art style is very charming, the lil spooky story is very interesting. But the game does feel a little half baked for a full release. There aren't very many locations to decorate, 15 at most which I feel is a very small amount for a full released game. I'm unsure of the developers plans for continued updates but I feel the game is missing a lot of content. There's so much potential here so I hope they continue support as this was a delightful little experience!

I've always been a big fan of the unpacking game, and it'll always hold a place in my heart. But I also feel like the developers took inspiration from it and went above and beyond with that concept. And to be honest, I'm all here for it!

Whispers of the House is a delightful, cozy game, coated with some mystery and secrets. Give or take, I may have missed some here and there. And even despite officially getting the thank you for playing end credits, I'm planning to jump in for another round. See if I can find some more, since I have at least one I haven't solved or figured out yet, and it has me intrigued. And this is special, at least to me, because we all know I can't play games back to back. Yet this one seems to be my one exception. At this point, I'm already hoping and rooting to see another one. I need more of this. A lot more.

That being said, I do have some feedback, but nothing that would be a deal breaker for me to stop playing. It's more about making minor improvements here and there. To make it even better!
*~One of those things is that I have no idea if I collected all the items. Okay, the ones you haven't bought yet, with the cute voucher system, are greyed out. But to me, that's still a bit unclear. I would love to see a counter that shows x out of 100 items so that I can be sure. 
*~I almost lost an item behind something I couldn't move, and it took me 20 minutes to get it back out from behind that thing. Perhaps for essential items, it wouldn't be a bad idea to have them reset when needed. Perhaps with a respawn button of some sorts? 
And there is a chance there were a few more thingies that I've forgotten about by now, since I recorded and played a few days ago. If needed, I'll update. <3

But that's it for me now, in a nutshell. I can wholeheartedly vouch for this little gem, and I genuinely hope to see another one, or some DLC, as I mentioned earlier. I think it's an amazing and fun game. One you don't want to stop playing. One that makes you relax and yet gives you that little bit of mystery, making you go oooh. Oowh. Ooooe! Cozy with a dash of excitement.

At some point, I'll probably update my review, possibly to make it a little more polished and all that, as this was drafted quickly to show my early support and in an attempt to lure you into playing... what? at least I'm honest!-since I genuinely feel like this one is so, so worth a playthrough. ^_^

Cute pixel art? Check.
Strange happenings? Check.
Tons of little plants? Check. 
Petting cats? Check check check!

Open world unpacking/decorating game. What's not to love? Can't wait to spend more time with this game.

I grew up playing The Sims and my favorite part was furnishing the homes. Whisper of the House scratches an itch that I've had for a long, long time. 

My only nits to pick:

- you can't turn objects diagonally
- some objects can only face 2 directions
- please make more objects
- please give us live animals
- I don't like the loot boxes

Everyone keeps comparing this one to unpacking,  but personally this game was more engaging to me.  I loved the little puzzles and i felt like you could interact with things more. It felt also extremely rewarding to find all the little secrets and Easter eggs. 
Overall i felt like this was a great game and worth buying.  Also i am glad i went into it without  knowing anything prior about the games world.  Basically what I am saying is that if you can avoid spoilers,  that would make the game more fun i think.

I enjoyed this game a great deal, and it's a bummer to not be able to recommend this game on the merits of what it does well - but it truly does feel like a half-finished experience.

The parts that work are wonderful and memorable - two levels early in the story have incredible hidden secrets that truly make you feel smart for figuring them out. But the back half of the game becomes repetitive and relatively uninteresting.

The game promises a great deal about a hidden story to unravel, but its most interesting ideas go totally unexplored and unexplained. There are big missing chunks of story here that can't help but feel like the dev just ran out of time, and disappointingly, it takes what could have been, I think, a truly incredible game to a pretty unmemorable one. The decorating is fun, but the economy has zero challenge whatsoever. You get thousands of 'vouchers' for completing easy in-game tasks, and after that can just spam the merchants, which only award furniture at random, to get everything you need. You can buy individual pieces - but only if you've unlocked them already, completely removing any incentive for doing so.

The decorating challenges, which I suspect were added to pad playtime, are pointless. Unlike some decorating games that 'tag' furniture with associated characteristics, adding an actual mechanic to decorating, the challenges in this game simply give you four or five pieces of furniture to put in a giant room, and then arbitrarily let you put down an amount of furniture (it never tells you how much). You could literally plonk down random items for ten seconds and would be rewarded with completing the challenge with full marks, which completely took the fun out of it for me.

The world-building is charming and the little interactions are super cool. The first two hours of this game showcase what it could have been, and I'm disappointed that it couldn't keep up that level of quality. Buy it on sale and enjoy it for what it is, but I can't recommend it for the listed price.

I love this game so much! â™¡ There's quite a lot of content and an underlying mystery to solve. I really appreciated the eerie vibes and decorating [spoiler] the graveyard [/spoiler] was my absolute favourite! We are given some decent freedom with organising and there are plenty of side missions where you are given a theme, some starting items, and then basically free reign to decorate as you see fit. And we can customise our own space too. Would love to see more of this cozy + spooky combination in the genre coming forward for sure!

I just got the end credits, but I don't have all the achievements yet, and it took me 6 hours. I had a lot of fun with this! There's several more in game things I can decorate and a lot of things left to collect, I also didn't spend much time on my own house - which I want to do. It's a fun little unpacking type game but with a lot of variety of homes and businesses, and theres some real spooky sht going on too which I like a lot. I'm also a scaredy cat with pretty much any kind of scary game and this isn't scary, just has some neat spooky vibes every so often.

I've been waiting for this game to release, The art-style and organising/decorating game play is what drew me in, after playing for couple of hours i have to say this game is amazing and will easily become one of my favourites the stroyline is engaging and actions you make contribute to the story i love that your able to walk around town and interact with everything, i would definitely recommend this game

ESPAÃ‘OL: 
Antes de nada quiero decir que todavÃ­a no me lo he pasado, he visto un par de bugs que ya he reportado pero me esta gustando y querÃ­a hacer la reseÃ±a para las personas que probaron la demo y no sabÃ­an si lo iban a modificar demasiado tras el incidente de la habitaciÃ³n secreta.

Whisper of the House es un juego para un solo jugador donde el objetivo principal es ayudar a tus nuevos vecinos a desempaquetar y decorar sus casas y negocios en una ciudad en crecimiento. Conforme avanzas, conoces nuevos personajes que abren sus propios locales y te piden ayuda para organizarlos, lo que da una sensaciÃ³n de progreso en la ciudad bastante agradable.

Lo que mÃ¡s me ha gustado:
-  Mantiene una atmÃ³sfera cozy, pero con un giro interesante: una historia de misterio que se va desarrollando mientras decoras. (Esto es lo que mÃ¡s me llamaba del juego y me alegro de que haya mantenido esa idea).
- Casi todos los objetos se pueden colocar en distintas posiciones, lo que da mucha libertad creativa. TambiÃ©n puedes modificar el suelo y pared de tu casa, aunque no en todas las zonas.
- Gran variedad de Ã­tems desbloqueables mediante el sistema tipo "gacha" (o gatcha), usando tickets que puedes conseguir buscando en la basura, vendiendo lo que no usas o cumpliendo tareas de decoraciÃ³n.


Lo que no me gusta:
- No entiendo el mensajito de que pasan los dÃ­as, igual he pasado algo por alto pero no le encuentro el sentido y me resulta a veces molesto.
- Creo que voy a conseguir todos los items de cajas demasiado rÃ¡pido porque me premian con demasiados tickets. Igual en un futuro van a tener que sacar una expansiÃ³n con mÃ¡s elementos decorativos para que pueda seguir gastando mis tickets, jajaja.

En general, es una propuesta diferente y muy entretenida. Si te gustan los juegos tranquilos de decoraciÃ³n, pero ademÃ¡s quieres una pizca de intriga, puede gustarte.

DEUTSCH:
Bevor ich anfange, mÃ¶chte ich sagen, dass ich das Spiel noch nicht durchgespielt habe.
Ich habe ein paar Bugs gefunden, die ich bereits gemeldet habe, aber mir gefÃ¤llt es bisher, und ich wollte eine Rezension schreiben â€“ vor allem fÃ¼r die Leute, die die Demo ausprobiert haben und nicht wussten, ob nach dem Vorfall mit dem geheimen Raum zu viel geÃ¤ndert werden wÃ¼rde.

Whisper of the House ist ein Einzelspieler-Spiel, bei dem das Hauptziel darin besteht, deinen neuen Nachbarn beim Auspacken und Einrichten ihrer HÃ¤user und GeschÃ¤fte in einer wachsenden Stadt zu helfen. WÃ¤hrend du voranschreitest, lernst du neue Charaktere kennen, die ihre eigenen LÃ¤den erÃ¶ffnen und dich bitten, ihnen bei der Organisation zu helfen. Dadurch entsteht ein sehr angenehmes GefÃ¼hl von Fortschritt in der Stadt.

Was mir am meisten gefallen hat:

- Es behÃ¤lt eine gemÃ¼tliche AtmosphÃ¤re bei, aber mit einem interessanten Twist: eine Mystery-Geschichte, die sich nach und nach entwickelt, wÃ¤hrend man dekoriert. (Das war das, was mich am meisten am Spiel gereizt hat, und ich freue mich, dass diese Idee beibehalten wurde).
- Fast alle Objekte kÃ¶nnen in verschiedenen Positionen platziert werden, was viel kreative Freiheit gibt. AuÃŸerdem kann man den Boden und die WÃ¤nde des eigenen Hauses verÃ¤ndern â€“ allerdings nicht in allen Bereichen.
- GroÃŸe Vielfalt an freischaltbaren Items durch ein Gacha-Ã¤hnliches System, mit Tickets, die man bekommen kann, indem man im MÃ¼ll sucht, unbenutzte Dinge verkauft oder Dekorationsaufgaben erfÃ¼llt.

Was mir nicht gefÃ¤llt:
- Ich verstehe die kleine Nachricht Ã¼ber die vergehenden Tage nicht. Vielleicht habe ich etwas Ã¼bersehen, aber fÃ¼r mich ergibt sie keinen Sinn und ist manchmal eher stÃ¶rend.
- Ich glaube, dass ich alle Items aus den Kisten zu schnell bekommen werde, weil man zu viele Tickets geschenkt bekommt. Vielleicht mÃ¼ssen sie in Zukunft eine Erweiterung mit mehr Dekorationsobjekten herausbringen, damit ich meine Tickets weiter ausgeben kann, haha.

Insgesamt ist es ein anderes, aber sehr unterhaltsames Spiel. Wenn du entspannte Dekorationsspiele magst, aber auch ein wenig Spannung haben mÃ¶chtest, kÃ¶nnte es dir gefallen.

ENGLISH:
First of all, I want to say that I havenâ€™t finished it yet.
Iâ€™ve found a couple of bugs, which I already reported, but Iâ€™m enjoying it so far and I wanted to write this review for people who tried the demo and werenâ€™t sure if they would change too much after the incident with the secret room.

Whisper of the House is a single-player game where the main goal is to help your new neighbors unpack and decorate their houses and businesses in a growing town. As you progress, you meet new characters who open their own shops and ask for your help to organize them, which gives a very pleasant sense of progress in the town.

What I liked the most:

- It keeps a cozy atmosphere but with an interesting twist: a mystery story that slowly unfolds while you decorate. (This is the thing that most attracted me, and Iâ€™m glad they kept that idea).
- Almost all objects can be placed in different positions, giving a lot of creative freedom. You can also change the floor and walls of your house, although not in every area.
- Great variety of unlockable items through a gacha-like system, using tickets you can get by searching the trash, selling unused items, or completing decoration tasks.

What I didnâ€™t like:

- I donâ€™t understand the little message about the passing days. Maybe I missed something, but it doesnâ€™t make sense to me and sometimes feels a bit annoying.
- I think Iâ€™m going to get all the items from boxes too quickly because they reward you with too many tickets. Maybe in the future theyâ€™ll have to release an expansion with more decorative items so I can keep spending my tickets, haha.

Overall, itâ€™s a different but very entertaining game. If you like relaxing decoration games but also want a pinch of intrigue, you might enjoy it.

Love this little cozy game. 13 hours of play and 100% achievement completion. I don't manage to do that with many games, but this one kept me wanting to do and explore more. The art style is lovely, and surprisingly detailed for a pixel based style. Music is pretty nice too. :)

Enjoyable simple decorating/cleaning gameplay with a somewhat intriguing story of cute characters.
Collecting items ended up not being that much of an interest to me - its very easy to get enough vouchers to just unlock everything (and have many left on your hands and nothing meaningful to spend it on). And the collection is somewhat limited, but still cute.
Also a little sad that you can't recolor most of the furniture (however the existence of a colorwheel is awesome and lets you recolor some items just how you want it). 

Controls are comfortable, graphics are cute
Sound is unintrusive and cozy
Story is simple but fun, gives you goals to complete
Short and sweet, completed in 7 hours.

update: it took me 9.4 hours to get all the achievements. now that i've finished, i can assuredly say i recommend this game. it might be my favourite game i've played this year! i plan to continue playing to decorate more homes, but even if you just want to play through the quests, it's well worth playing. thank you devs for making such an awesome game! x

original review: i only clicked because i thought it'd be similar to unpacking, and while i thought the price was steep at first, i really wanted my home-decorating fix so i bought it anyways. so happy i did. it's been worth every penny and then some.

the core gameplay loop is the same as unpacking, yes, but this game has way more optional and side content. there are lots, and i mean LOTS of easter eggs, item interactions, and little puzzles tucked away. you could speed through the quests in just a few hours, but slowing down and taking your time is so much more rewarding. i've seen a few reviews say they finished the game within 3 hours... but i'm almost positive those people missed some content.

the pixel art is beautiful, the colours are easy on the eyes, and the music is calm and non-intrusive. unlike unpacking, you can actually walk around, talk to characters, and personally interact with objects. there's even an in-game gacha that uses in-game currency, perfect for people (like me) who love meta progression.

when it comes to decorating, there are tons of furniture pieces and design options if you want to get creative and make things your own. on the flip side, you can also just use what's given to you and not worry too much about customisation if that's not your thing.

i don't mean to say unpacking is badâ€”far from it. it's an incredible game and defined the whole genre. but whisper of the house takes that blueprint to the next level.

it won't give you the classic "$1 per hour" value ratio, but every hour iâ€™ve spent here has been of the highest quality and absolutely worth it. i would love, LOVE a dlc for this game, and would gladly pay extra for it.
It was a really good game. The city felt alive while playing and the characters were well written.

[b] An open world Unpacking! â™¡ [/b]

I am so in love with this game that I donâ€™t want it to end! :(

It reminds me of some of my favorites: Unpacking, Stardew Valley, and Pixel Room Generator. I can see how it drew inspiration from these and turned it into an absolutely addicting gem. I can easily see myself playing for hours, designing rooms with different themes. I love the quests and how I can freely roam around town! Right-clicking the anomalies is also so satisfying.

Thereâ€™s always something cozy about pixel games paired with the right music. I think itâ€™s fairly priced for what you get and definitely deserves the overwhelmingly positive reviews.

Seen most of the reviews (regardless) but still decided to give this game a try since I personally love arranging things. 
It has been a fun and therapeutic game for me. The movements of the character is also relatively smooth, luv it.

However, with that being said, the game interface could have been better if it is a little more flexible in allowing us to turn all the objects 360 degree (and not selected ones). Also, I thought the rooms could be rotated but nope...its fixed.

So...other than the rotations, the game is generally great if you are someone who likes to arrange things.

What a wonderful game! This definitely scratched that Unpacking type itch for me, and bonus points for having a lot of leeway in placing items and not being forced into putting things in certain spots to proceed. It look me 8 hours to 100% achievements, though keep in mind there hadn't been any guides created yet when I was playing so that last hour was mostly hunting for the last few.

I think there are a couple improvements that could be made to the end and translations especially, if things were worded a bit better it would make things a lot more clearer to understand story-wise. But for me the gameplay is what I came for - and it very pleasantly exceeded my expectations. 

Some super creative level design here, and I love the option to play even longer with all the showroom options and personal houses to decorate if you wish. Would love to see more like this in the future.

Whisper of the House: a cozy pixel escape with a sprinkle of magic

If you're looking for a game to gently peel your brain out of burnout mode and wrap it in a warm, pixelated hug... this is it.

You get to unpack, clean, decorate, and vibe your way through charming little houses full of secrets, sparkles, and the occasional magical surprise. Think Unpacking, but with more whimsical lore and the occasional ghost.

The story is light and easy to follow. No over-complicated timelines or existential dread here. Just cozy mystery with a side of mild enchantment. The gameplay is smooth, intuitive, and blessedly ADHD-friendly. I 100%'d the whole thing in about 6 hours, and not once did my attention decide to yeet itself into the void.

The pixel art? Adorable.
The atmosphere? Relaxing.
The soundtrack? Melted into the background like a cup of warm tea and never once annoyed me.

Top moments? The graveyard setting and EinSmart's Secret Lab made me do that little gamer giggle of joy when things are just right.

So if youâ€™re into games that let you decorate, discover secrets, and unwind without the pressure of combat or cryptic puzzles... this oneâ€™s for you.
Would recommend to anyone who enjoyed Unpacking, adores cute pixel art, or wants a whisper of the supernatural without the threat of possession.

Final verdict?
â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸ Cozy chaos with a ghostly wink.

Even with my review, I thoroughly have enjoyed this game. It is quite simply an overarching mix between Unpacking, the Animal Crossing Happy Homes DLC, and it's own thing entirely. My major issues stem from the fact that the game barely teaches you how to play outside of the basic click and drag items function, as well as the lack of room interaction. I've not had the game explain to me anything about how to get more items, anything about its apparent cleaning of the city, it's scavenging mechanic, or anything really. My other major issue is it's lack of room storage. You're given food items, small bits and bobs, clothing, etc, yet nowhere to place them. For the majority of the game you have no closets, drawers, fridges, nothing. Nothing to open or store things in. This to me is extremely essential to a storage and decor game like this. Hopefully this can be changed in the future, as the game has a sort of professional class that is hard to find nowadays; that is to say it can definitely hold its own. I hope to be able to change this someday, either way thank you for the fun I did have, and heres to hopefully having more in the future.
